												Still Life 2, ironically enough, is a work-of-art doomed to muuuurrrrder. I absolutely loved the first one back in '05 and just recently found out (06-2014) that the sequel actually got released. And, though I loathe online videogame criticism because of the era of repetitive flash we live in, (i.e. the move forward and shoot, and do it again games) ya just can't help but accidently read them as you learn when the hell the game got made. I know I'm a hypocrite -- so doesn't that nullify itself?Still Life 2, according to every review I've read anywhere, was supposed to suck like a '93 hoover -- reliably, but you have to lug it around. The whole time I was waiting for this horrible game to happen. Ya know what? The game is great -- the era is wrong. See, if this game came out before we were spoiled be an entire Saw movie franchise and golden globe actors voicing over in games like Mass Effect, than people would remember this game as a tense sequel worthy of a trilogy -- that I wish would happen, but now can't (Post Mortem to me is more of a pre-series). It's the same reason you can't have "iso-games" like Baldur's Gate anymore. Anybody growing up with videogames just after Pong -- like my 80's generation, can appreciate games that are older. We'd rather have awesome gameplay and out-of-the-box thinking over next-gen graphics. I.E. we'd take this game over your leading flashy graphics, first-person "move-forward and shoot" game (not mentioning titles so people don't get distracted off the point).I hate listing bugs because it's almost like when you do people seem to think that the game in question is the only one with them -- ever. Pong use to freeze -- every game has bugs. The only two I saw through this game was one that blacked the visuals when I talked to a person without first having an item in my inventory (you'll know when you walk away from the npc and your screen blacks-out for a second that this bug will soon happen to you unless you fix the cause by getting that item, then talking to the person), and the fact that when the "that won't work" speech happens it's always Hernandez and not McPherson no matter who you are playing (I image they are missing a line of code that signifies McPherson is b*****ing -- or when she gets frustrated she does impressions). Those were the only bugs seen in a game that was release online in Germany and almost not released in the US. Usually games that end with that sentence are for your iPad-Tabl-a-Phone -- so the fact that a game that looks like it's comparable to the first one visually and has the same feel made it on the pc should be celebrated more than it is. Kind of like the Star Trek 25th Anniversary sequel Judgment Rites -- which had no bussiness not getting a graphics overhall -- but back then we didn't care 'cause it was it's sequel (it was suppose to look the same).This game will not go over well with people who strictly like Call of Duty or MMO's -- 'cause it's an adventure/detective game. That said, many people had trouble with the puzzles and found them agitating. Puzzles are agitating -- that's why they are puzzles, that's why they are fun. Again with the generational thing -- in a world where we purchase things online and text each other for instant gratification -- this game will be lost on some due to the hours of thought that may go into one puzzle. I know kids in this generation that, if they can't figure out a reply to their text message will put people on ignore -- so yeah. Some puzzles make no sense at all to the player -- because they only make sense to the bad-guy -- if you think "what would I do if I were a pixelated linear homicidal bas**** with the need to write things down somewhere?" you'll do alright.The Plot. Let’s start with Sarah Leger aka the voice of Victoria McPherson. I like her voice and her commitment to a videogame character -- back before people started to really give a s*** about the how artistic that kind of thing was. She was great in Still Life and she's great in Still Life 2. Worthy of her own mini-series. The other characters... Vary. Now, again we live in an age where Martin Sheen will act in your videogame -- we use to live in an age when Scott McCulloch would voice your Player 1. Who the hell is Scott McCulloch? Chris freak'n Redfield, Resident Evil Director's Cut on the PS1 -- that's who. My point is it's a videogame and they get a very limit budget compared to hollywood -- if the gameplay is solid and fun and the plot drives it forward then do you really expect the Sheriff of Mayberry to quote Hamlet?So the plot. Again, if it wasn't for the fact Saw made so many of these damn things it would've been cutting-edge *snicker*. But it's still good. I don't know what people wanted. It's the only game of its kind -- where it doesn't focus on the brutality of Saw, and for the most part you are in the aspect of the Agent after the killer. It also fills in the gap between the first game and second -- affirming what you should've known about who the first killer was, but didn't get spoon-fed.This also confused people: so let me just say -- if Victoria is wearing a black turtleneck sweater she's in a flash-back just after the events of Still Life 1, and if she's not then she's naked. Well she's not ever -- never mind. Also they flash the date -- so, if you are one of the people that still can't get this new-fangled plot concept I hear the latest battlefield has new DLC again.The problem is despite the negative reviews, it's not the plot, it's the execution *snicker*. See, the killer (I don't want to give any spoilers) doesn't believe in his own motivations because the writer didn't (unlike in the first where they mirrored Jack the Ripper -- so they didn't have to understand -- they had a pallete). Speaking as a psychopath (that is not synonymous with killer) with no real respect for modern day society I can tell you my reasons are more adult then "it's liberating" to not care about society. The motivation for an intellectual is to realize that society as a whole is a lie to cover up what we don't want to expose to others. Dexter was a great show that captured this ideal. The killer's motivation in this game is more like a teenager that didn't get his way, than an adult who's tired of watching people stupider (yes that's a word -- stupidest didn't use to be a word -- now who the hell knows) than him destroy possibilities around him.But that's the only undertone I think people don't like here. Take away that melodrama and the plot is solid and fun. And hell -- with the melodrama in -- had Leger not had to carry everyone, it could've been a made-for-tv movie.What I'm saying is -- it's a videogame -- it was a truly interesting sequel being that it took the Agent-to-victim twist like you didn't expect from a sequel that almost didn't happen. It also closed all the question you had in the first one. I hope for some reason Microids of France releases a Still Life 3 and they mail me a copy.Recommendation: Still Life 1 = Ripping good time, Still Life 2 = Buzz Worthy.

												A few years ago, when I first played Still Life, I was blown away by the mature nature of it. My point-and-click experiences had been games that could be geared for the whole family. I had recently played Syberia and when I saw that Still LIfe was done by the same publisher I jumped at the opportunity to take on the Still Life saga. Still Life was a great and gritty game and the story continues in Still Life 2.At the end of Still Life, it appears that Agent Vic McPherson has stopped the main antagonist of the game, but we the players never felt the strong resolution of knowing the identity of the killer, or if he was dead for that matter. In this game, we receive closure, and a whole lot more. There are many twists and turns in the plot that make playing SL1 absolutely necessary. However, the story is solid, and the plight of the two heroines of this game is very believable.Our two heroines are of course Agent McPherson as she tries to bring another serial killer to justice, while trying to resolve issues that deal with the first game. The other protagonist is a reporter named Paloma Hernandez. She gets kidnapped by said serial killer and must try to survive his games. This makes the game have two different tones, and helps with the pacing. As Mcpherson, you have a field kit, and you are acting like an agent would: sweeping a crime scene for clues, conducting forensics tests, putting together the facts. Very little point-and-click puzzles, but actual detective work. It really gave the game a sense of realism. Then you switch to the hell that Hernandez is facing and the game changes. This particular serial killer likes to play games with his victims to see if their lives are worth living. This is where the puzzles come in. They are not horribly difficult since they are constrained to certain areas, but the pressure is on and the tension is high. It feels like a serious accomplishment each time you beat the killer at his own game. He is also impressed by the way. Now I would like to address some game mechanics that seem to get some slack from other reviewers. In this game, you have an inventory limit, and I love that. It's realistic! You can only hide so much in a short skirt and tank top! There are various areas in which you can store items for later use, and there are a fair number of them, so backtracking shouldn't be a huge problem. It wasn't for me anyway. Also, there are timed puzzles/scenarios. Sometimes you only have so much time to react or bad things will happen. This is not like in other games where you stand still and the game will wait for you to make it to the next checkpoint. No, this game really tries to be realistic as far as letting you know that in some life and death situations, you don't have a lot of time!The graphics for this game do not have the same quality as the first game. But then again, the game takes place mostly in a serial killer's lair and house, so how pretty would you want that to look? The graphics are gritty, not pretty and glossy, and to me it works. The cut scenes are great, and once you watch them you can rewatch them in the main menu. Yeah, I've rewatched a few... The voice acting for the most part is great. Some of the animations, especially during conversations can look a little awkward since the characters keep repeating the same gestures, but the voice acting carries. There have been some complaints of bugs, and while I did encounter a bug near the end of the game, I found a way around it. If you are concerned about bugs, wait for a sale. Overall, this was a great game that reminded me more of a real detective investigation than a point-and-click adventure game. The game wrapped up all the loose ends of the first game and came to a fitting conclusion for both heroines...if you do everything right of course :) .

Still Life 2			* 5/10Still Life 2 is a detective point & click adventure sequel to the very dense and dark first Still Life. We're taking control of Victoria McPherson once again in this really requested second chapter, as the story in the first one ended in an ambiguous and ominous way (which is great for a dark game like that, in my opinion). Years after the first chapter Microids decided to work again on the brand preparing this sequel. There are few innovations in the game mechanics like the inventory slots, or the CSI portable Kit. Another thing remains: the dual character. You will control both Victoria McPherson with her investigations and Paloma Hernandez a kidnapped journalist trying to escape or at the very least survive her kidnapper.Unfortunately even though the story has some good ideas vith few great plot twists really unexpected, really looks like a game badly or quickly developed, as this chapter is supposed to close the story of the first Still Life. And it does, but in a very brief and unsatisfactory way. And while in the first chapter we saw a wide variety of beautiful and different locations, this time we are stuck in a house... Definitely not worth the first chapter. +++PROs+++ DIALOGUES. In the first chapter you could simply use left or right mouse click to talk about "investigations" or "generic Conversation". In this chapter you can choose exactly what to talk about, which is something that I really missed. GAMEPLAY. A very pleasant new addition in the gameplay is the CSI kit. It might look some kind of boring routine but I admit I really loved Vic's parts in which she goes around locations collecting clues and analyzing them.---CONs--- STEAM OVERLAY. It doesn't work. I like to always take many photos while ingame, but in this case I can't because the overlay doesn't work. Even if there's the notification as soon as the game loads. I'm not the only one but seems like nobody knows a solution or workaround. And ( most ridiculous part) The Overlay perfectly works in the first chapter. GRAPHIC. I can forgive the first chapter but this game was released in 2009 and you can't set your resolution nor you can set it in 16:9 because it was designed to work on 4:3... in 2009?! Meh... CAMERA. Unlike the first chapter's static camera, this second chapter has a dynamic camera, following the protagonist along the scenario, until it has to change completely view or angle. This could have worked well if only the camera wasn't that clumsy meaning it follows too much in some situations getting in the way and preventing you from switching angle easily, while in other situations the camera doesn't switch when it should, preventing you from reaching certain places or items to interact on. Besides that, the camera movement is quite... rigid. Not much pleasant to view in various situations. DIALOGUES. Seriously, why do you always have the choice to beg for the kidnapper to set you free? Every time? Meh, that doesn't feel natural or credible. I mean, maybe the first times, but all the times... Really? Besides, main character's voice seems recorded fine, while some secondary characters sound kind of... amateur recorded. The audio quality sounds quite poor. Also during dialogues characters often repeat the same animation in loop... Even if they're not speaking SETTING. Most of the story happens inside a house and its surroundings. Honestly the ambience is nice as well as the idea, but an entire game inside there? Nope, it didn't work well, I couldn't wait to finish the game. STORY.  Actually the idea behind the game isn't that bad, as well as the house situation. It also had a couple of plot twists that I really didn't expect and gave me some motivation on the game, but the fact that the plot twists kept on going until the situation fell on a cliché ( and quite non-credible) and the use (almost abuse) of a couple of minor and brief flashbacks that conclude the First Still Life story in a very quick and almost unlinked way really makes me feel like this game was really fast planned and quickly produced just to exploit the name with a game that has a couple of good ideas badly developed. INTERFACE. Sometimes the sensitive zones/icons for items to interact with are oddly placed or completely misplaced. In a point & click adventure that's really bad... BUGS. It often happened I was stuck and I couldn't move after analyzing an item, or calling Claire, or using the computer. Saving the game in that position and reloading didn't change anything, but luckily I always had a previous savegame close enough, so loading a game and repeating actions seems solve the problem. Still very annoying because it relies on the frequency of your savegames.

Short version: 23%Do you know those cheap, low-rated, horrible direct-to-video sequels that often have nothing to do with the original films apart from using their title? Still Life 2 is the point ‘n’ click equivalent of those.Long version: While it’d be hard to say Still Life was the most original adventure game ever made with its obvious Jack the Ripper storyline, at least it had its own memorable style both with the cast and the scenery, and it also had two interesting plot lines with almost perfect pacing.Still Life 2 just feels like as if someone found a rejected script for the never-made Kiss the Girls 2, changed the title, spent a couple hundred dollars on development, and hoped that somebody will eventually buy it.Everything in this game is bland. The environment is cheap 3D with bad camera movement and boring brown textures instead of the unique art déco scenery that gave the first game its distinct atmosphere. The cast was replaced with a bunch of interns doing their first voice acting job. The characters are Z-grade thriller cut-outs without any memorable features.The story is just boring. Surprisingly boring for a thriller about a serial killer who holds a known television reporter hostage in a mansion stolen right from a Saw movie, with the most ludicrous traps planted everywhere. You have zero incentive to progress, especially when you are presented with the one-hour clue-gathering tasks that repeat the same actions over two dozen times.And as a final insult, there are the twists. They just keep going and going: every time you think you finally reached the end, you suddenly discover a new part of this endless maze of a mansion with another impossible hurdle to overcome by a set of illogical and unintuitive puzzles that always manage to involve inventory management busywork. And at every new twist you seriously question your decision to ever start this game, which is probably one of the biggest mistakes anyone can make.

the inventory system (when it's full, you have to store away whatever's not needed at the time in nearby stashes & containers)- time-sensitive objectives (making things a bit harder & more thrilling)- the scenery & in-game music- the implementation of flashbacks weaved in the story**This is my second time playing this game, and I just stopped because I couldn't bare the bugs (or voice-scripting anymore).This game takes perseverance & patience to complete!------------------------------------------------EXTRA INFO:- during one of the cutscenes, the main char (aka Vic McPherson) speaks in a French accent, instead of an American accent (this is most probably because the development team decided to make a switch at some point, and forgot to adjust that part)- in yet another scene, there's a serial killer, dubbed the "East Coast Killer" who is known to use a voice-transformer during interactions with the press & the police (in-game), and at some point his actual voice is revealed during one of his recording sessions (to this day, I'm still not sure whether this was done intentionally, or was a blunder)On a final note, if anybody decides to get the game, make sure to get it on sale and think of storing game progress regularly!PS the use of the neat CSIA kit + the smartphone (in game) really kept me going!And of course, the main character is a tough nut to crack! Personal Rating: 6/10 - category "point&click"As a big fan of Still Life 1, I was really looking forward to playing this game, but sadly I got really dissapointed.The only reason why I kept playing and even finished it, was the main character, Victoria McPherson, which is still one of my favourite video game characters ever. Whoever designed her, and then also chose the perfect voice actor for her, thank you!Quick overview: The game has a lot of control issues, a lot of bugs and overall a poor storyline. The locations as well as the soundtrack are quite repetitive. The voice acting is fine (Victoria is great as always!). The graphics are okay, while the cinematic cutscenes are pretty amazing and bring a lot of atmosphere into the game. The puzzles sometimes are ridiculously hard and make no sense, I had to check a walkthrough quite a few times. If you're a big fan of Still Life 1, you still might wanna play part 2 out of curiosity. But I wouldn't recommend it to any other people, especially not to those, who haven't played Still Life 1. To them, the story would make almost no sense and would be even more boring, since they don`t have the background knowledge about the characters and the story from part 1.Plot:Well, the plot is a pretty simple one and nothing out of the ordinary. It is linked to Vic's past, but I won't spoil any more details here. There`s a serial killer on the loose, called "The East coast killer" by the media, and he is after young women. Paloma Hernandez, a young, female, reporter gets involved and becomes one of his prisoners; but our alltime favourite (ex-) FBI Agent is on the case. What makes the story a little more interesting, is the few and short trips to Vic's past, where you find out what happened after the ending of SL1 and how she happened to get to where she is now; why she left the FBI, what became of the killer and what happened between her and her boyfriend. Characters:There are two playable characters in the game, one being Victoria, the FBI Agent, and the other one being Paloma Hernandez, a female reporter, which investigates on the serial killer case for the media and then becomes one of the killer's victims. She is made, so that she's not liked by the audience, because she bad-mouthes Victoria in her news reports and talks badly about her investigation progress on the serial killer case. As soon as she becomes a victim and thereby playable, the player is meant to sympathize with her - which didn't really succeed for me. I found her quite annoying and pretty "flat" as a character still. Controls - Walking:The controls are really messy and sometimes hard to understand. You click on any point on the screen, and the character will walk there. If you double click, she will even run there, which is at least an improvement compared to the first game. At the same time, the camera will move around as you walk across the room, which often leads to complications when you want to reach a specific spot and the camera is giving you a hard time going there. Controls - Inventory:ugh. The inventory. What can I say, it is one of the worst, I have ever seen. As in SL1, it takes you quite a while to figure out how it works, it is absolutely not intuitive. It's not explained anywhere in the game and you just have to figure it out by trying. The inventory is made up of 3 different parts; your personal storage, your mobile phone that stores data for you (pictures, clues and objectives), and your FBI testing kit that has a lot of tools to analyze clues that you find. This testing kit is a very cool and creative idea, but it lacks importance for the overall game and could have been refined to become more effective for the gameplay. Your personal storage is an inventory that has only a few, limited slots. Why did they do that? For a point&click game it is essential to have all the items you find always at hand, so you can try them out, combine them and test them on other interactive objects. This system however forces you, to decide on a few things to carry around, and leave the rest of them in various storage places (there are 4 in total, but not all are always accesable). The thing is, that some of the items you find, you can/have to use multiple times, so you never exactly know, when you could need which item. So there's a lot of running around just to get to the storage places. Sometimes you forgot in which of those you stored your desired item, which means even more senseless running around. Which is especially a lot of fun, when you are in a timed event, where the clock is counting down, and if you can't do it in time, you die. yay. :) Also, figuring out how the storage even works, is a puzzle itself, but unintened. I had to google it, to find out how/where to click into the storage, to store an item there. Absolutely ridiculous.Puzzles:The puzzles are interesting but too hard. Often they make no sense, concerning which item you have to use to solve it, and which cannot be used, even if it would make sense to do so.What's positive is, that there are a few puzzles that can be solved in different ways and with different items. Also, you can use some objects more than 1 time, which actually makes sense. Why would I throw away my cool pocket-knife in a situation like that?What I also liked, was that there are timed puzzle events, where you have only a certain amount of time to figure out what to do. This is especially cool, as it fits to the story - there's a killer about to kill your friend - you have to act quickly or else she will die! If you can`t do it, it's game over and you have to reload the game.

												Since 2005, I had been dying to play the sequel to Still Life. It ended with a cliffhanging ending that was painful to not know the identity of the Masked Killer. I got worried when I heard rumors about Still Life 2's cancellation soon after that but now that I have finally completed the game, I wish it stayed lost in the abyss.Still Life 2 is a major disappointment on so many levels. The first thing is the quality itself; the character would stutter when it collides with an object, the gameplay is so stiff and the the lighting is lacking. As you play, you will feel disoriented interacting with the environment because the point n click mechanics is so wonky like it goes against your gameplay instinct. It's very hard to explain.I'm especially disappointed with the visuals as it looks nothing like the original. Although it is commendable that they switched from pre-rendered backgrounds to full 3D but I wish they had stuck with the former even though it may look outdated. There is absolutely no facial expression or motion capture in  the characters and the voice acting is really bad. It's so silly to see a bunch of people standing idly like toy soldiers.The puzzles are not that fun either. They are not as cryptic as that stupid lockpicking and cooking puzzles in Still Life 1 but in here, there's so little hints and to make matters worse, there's time limit! This goes against the rules of Adventure games. I find myself looking at walkthroughs, which I didn't do in the previous game.The only word I can describe Still Life 2 is "suck." The overall experience was just painful and a huge letdown. The only reason why I presevered to complete it was to find out who the Masked Killer was but when he did reveal himself, I was shocked to learn that this was not the main storyline but as a flashback. It turns out that Still Life 2 tells a different story about a new protagonist that I don't care about. That's right. You control 2 characters; one is Agent Vic McPherson of course and the other is some scumbag reporter that has nothing to do with the Masked Killer plotline.Completing the game really left a bad taste in my mouth. I didn't feel accomplished. I felt betrayed; betrayed by the developers who made this crappy follow up. I strongly feel that Still Life 2 was released in Beta and that no effort was put in the story, programming, and testing. I know because I'm in the gaming business. Sorry Mircroids but this game is the worst yet. Not even Unity and Unreal can save this mess. To those who have completed Still Life 1 and is dying to know who the Masked Killer is...just look it up on the Internet. Trust me. Playing the sequel is just not worth it.
